choices.choice: He will buy the blouse for twenty dollars.
He will see Betty this weekend.
He will borrow some money from the woman and buy the blouse.
He will let Betty pay back the money as soon as possible.

AssessmentItem.Script: M: I'd like to buy this blouse for Betty's birthday, but I'm twenty dollars short. W: I'll lend you the money if you can pay me back by this weekend. Q: What will the man most probably do?

choices.choice: She has already lost her husband.
She has lived with her son.
She likes shopping with her son.
She goes to see her own mother twice a month.

AssessmentItem.Script: W: Hey, how do you spend your weekends usually? M: I go to see my mother, a 72-year-old widow, every other week, and go shopping with my wife for the rest of the time. Q: What do we know about the man's mother?

choices.choice: He might not be able to attend the ceremony.
He is not going to graduate this semester.
He hasn't been able to find a job.
He has to pass his final test.

AssessmentItem.Script: W: Jerry said he would come to my graduation ceremony. M: But he has to work that week, doesn't he? Q: What does the man imply about Jerry?

choices.choice: Tom's parents will leave for Angeles on Monday.
Tom has left for Los Angeles.
Tom has decided not to go to Los Angeles.
Tom's parents went to Los Angeles.

AssessmentItem.Script: M: Have Tom's parents left for Los Angeles yet? W: I think so. I called their house last night, but there was no answer. They probably left on Monday. Q: What did the man learn from the woman?

choices.choice: To buy the man a car.

AssessmentItem.Script: W: How can I find a good second-hand car? M: Why don't you try looking in the newspaper? Q: What does the woman want to buy?

choices.choice: Either milk or sugar in her coffee.

AssessmentItem.Script: M: Would you like milk or sugar in your coffee? W: Neither, thank you. Q: What does the woman want?

choices.choice: Give Marsha a check for the bookshelf she sold him.
Ask Marsha where she wants to put the bookshelf.
Check for the book on Marsha's shelf.
Ask Marsha if she has an extra bookshelf.

AssessmentItem.Script: W: Do you know anyone who has a spare bookshelf? M: Have you checked with Marsha? Q: What does the man suggest the woman do?

choices.choice: She is going to the lecture.
She is going to the school auditorium.
She is going to the museum.
She is going to stay home.

AssessmentItem.Script: M: Do you want to listen to the lecture in the school auditorium this Wednesday? W: I'd like to, but I'm going to the museum that day. Thanks for asking, though. Q: What does the woman mean?

question.Script: What kind of movie is the girl going to see on her date?
At what theater is the movie playing?

choices.choice: She is getting a ride with Dirk's brother.
Her date is coming to pick her up.
She is going by bus and will meet her date there.
Her father is going to drive her to the theatre.

question.Script: How is the girl getting to the movie?
What time does the movie begin?

AssessmentItem.Script: W: He's here. Bye Dad. M: Wait, wait, wait . . . Where are you going? W: Dad. I've already told mom. I'm going out tonight. M: Who with? You mean you're going on a date? W: Yeah. Mom met Dirk yesterday. [Dirk!?] He's so cool. We're going on a double-date with Cindy and Evan. M: Dirk? W: I have to go. M: Wait, wait. I want to meet this guy. W: He's waiting for me. M: Well, so what are you going to do tonight? Going to the library? W: Dad! We're going out to eat, and then we're going to catch a movie. M: What movie and what is it rated? W: It's a science fiction thriller called . . . well, I don't know what it is called, but it's rated Parental Guidance. M: And where's the movie showing? W: Down at the Oriental Garden Movie Theater. M: Hey, I was thinking about seeing a movie down there tonight, too. W: Ah, Dad. M: Hey, Let me meet that guy. Hey, that guy has a moustache! W: Dad. That's not Dirk. That's his older brother. He's taking us there! Can I go now? M: Well . . . W: Mom said I could, and mom knows his parents. M: Well . . . W: Dad. M: Okay, but be home by 8:00. W: Eight!? The movie doesn't start until 7:30. Come on, Dad. M: Okay. Be back by 11:00. W: Love you, Dad. M: Love you, too. W: Bye. M: Bye.

choices.choice: He cannot move as quickly and actively as he was young.
His aging life is frustrating and disappointing.

question.Script: Why does the man think his life is a bit inconvenient?

choices.choice: An aging man can be more interesting.
An aging man can be wealthier.
An aging man can be more knowledgeable.
An aging man can be luckier.

question.Script: According to the man, what does aging benefit him?

AssessmentItem.Script: W: Now, do you mind my asking how old you are? M: I was 80 years old on December 25th, 2006. W: Wow! 80! What does it feel like to be 80? M: It's a little inconvenient because my mind didn't turn 80 but my body did and I find sometimes my mind follows my body too! W: For example? M: It's hard to be as quick as I used to be and I can't do what I used to do when I was younger. W: Oh, that's disappointing and probably a little frustrating. M: Very frustrating! Especially when you have been active all of your life and all of a sudden, things begin to slow down. W: Well, are there any advantages? Can you give us some hope? M: Yes! Yes! There is hope. You have reached an age where you understand where you have been. W: Could you explain it in more details? M: I'm very fortunate that I lived in this age. I was born in 1926. I saw the airplane invented. I saw so many things, e.g. World War II, etc. W: World war II? M: Yes, World War II. I was married during World War II. So it's a good time. At 80 when you look back on all those things, you begin to understand the changes.You just become more knowledgeable when you become old. W: Well, that doesn't sound so bad.

choices.choice: Hamburger is young people's favorite food.
People often have hamburgers with ketchup.
Hamburger is children's idea of a good meal.

question.Script: Which of the following can't be inferred from the passage?

choices.choice: Hamburgers are often delivered to homes.
It is easy for people to get hamburgers.
Many people have their hamburgers outside restaurants.

question.Script: Which of the following is NOT true?

AssessmentItem.Script: The younger members of most American families don't like foreign food. They like hamburgers. Their idea of a good meal is a hamburger served with ketchup and French fried potatoes, which are called French fries. French fries are not considered foreign: most American children and teenagers love to eat them any time of the day or night. Millions of hamburgers and French fries are eaten every year. Thousands of roadside restaurants prepare and sell them. These are not really restaurants in the usual sense; they often have little space for tables and chairs. Many people buy their hamburgers and take them home to eat, or eat them in their cars. Sometimes it is not necessary to go inside in order to buy the hamburgers. They are ordered through a window in the restaurant and then are handed out through the window to the waiting customer. Sometimes the customer does not even have to get out of his car. When an American family travels abroad, this is almost always the custom that the younger members of the family miss most.

choices.choice: When someone has done harm to him.
When someone in a shop has served him.
When someone has given him a gift.

question.Script: When doesn't an American say "Thank you"?
How does an American feel when he is thanked again and again?

choices.choice: Empty thanks make Americans less anxious to help you.
It's not necessary to tell an American that your English is not good enough.
No one should apologize to an American for not being able to speak very good English.

question.Script: Which of the following is NOT true?

AssessmentItem.Script: "Thank you" means that you appreciate what someone has done for you, very often, very small and most ordinary things. So we in the West thank people all day long. For instance, you will thank the saleswoman after she has attended to you. You will say "Thank you" to the waitress when she brings you a cup of coffee. And a teacher will say "Thank you" to a student who has just answered the question. At home, the husband will thank the wife when she brings him a glass of water. However, too many expressions of gratitude give Westerners the sense of empty thanks, and make them uncomfortable. For example, if an American has spent half an hour helping you write some letters, you will, of course, want to say, "Thank you, I really appreciate your time." That's enough. If you go on and on with statements of thanks, and even add "I'm sorry to have wasted so much of your time", he will feel himself not thanked but annoyed and will not be anxious to help you again. And if he gets really annoyed, he might say, "Well, if you really think that you are wasting my time, you had better stay out of my way." There is also no need for you to apologize for your not being able to speak good English wherever you go and whomever you meet.

question.Script: Which of the following topics is not covered in the passage?

choices.choice: A meal can be cooked at the touch of the switch.
You can get the prices of local shops from television.
People making telephone calls can see each other.
Machines can be used to control climate.

question.Script: Which of the following is not possible in the year 2020?
How long will the normal holiday be in a year?
Which of the following is true according to the passage?

choices.choice: More people will travel to other countries.
People will spend less time on education.
International travel will not be too difficult.
More people will like to take holidays in winter.

question.Script: Which of the following is not true according to the passage?

AssessmentItem.Script: What will happen in the year 2020? Well, in the home, cookers will be set so that you can cook a complete meal at the touch of a switch. Television will provide information on prices at the nearby shops as well as news and entertainment. Videophones will bring pictures as well as sound to telephone conversations. Machines will control temperature, lighting, entertainment, security alarms and gardening. Lighting will provide decoration as well as wallpaper. At work, robots will take over most jobs in the manufacturing industries. Working hours will fall to under 30 hours a week. Holidays will get longer. Six weeks will be the normal annual holiday. Men and women will retire at the same age. Our leisure will be different too. The home will become the center of entertainment through television and electronic games. More people will eat out in restaurants than they do today; also they will have a much wider variety of food available. Foreign travel will increase; winter holidays will become more popular than summer ones. Also non-stop flights among different countries will be cheap and easily available. Hobbies and education will become increasingly important.

AssessmentItem.Content: The first true piece of sports equipment (_1_) was the ball. In ancient Egypt, as everywhere, pitching stones was a (_2_). But a badly thrown rock (_3_). Looking for something less dangerous to throw, the Egyptians made (_4_). At first, balls (_5_) held together by vines. Later they were made of pieces of animal skin sewed together and (_6_). Even though the Egyptians were warlike, they (_7_). Before long they had developed a number of ball games, (_8_). Perhaps they played ball (_9_). Ball playing was thought of mainly as a way to teach young men the speed and skill (_10_).

Answer.Value: what were probably the first balls
were made of grass or leaves
each with its own set of rules
more for instruction than for fun

AssessmentItem.Content: If you partied hard on 31st night to welcome the New Year, then there's nothing worse than waking up with a hangover（宿醉）. Then why didn't you think before (_1_) those drinks? Believe it or not, there are (_2_) with which you can prevent hangovers. (_3_) of all don't drink! Well that really isn't an (_4_) this season, is it? To begin with, eat a large meal before you (_5_) start drinking. Have a glass of water between drinks once you start to drink. You can drink orange juice as it is a good (_6_) for hangovers. The sugar in the fruit gives you a boost（提高） of energy. Avoid fizzy（起泡沫的） drinks as they actually (_7_) up the alcohol absorption process so you get intoxicated（喝醉的） faster. Avoid coffee as the caffeine in it dehydrates（[使]脱水） you just like alcohol. Eat (_8_) as they are a natural enticer that helps cure nausea（恶心）. (_9_) that, it is also high on magnesium（[化]镁） that can relax the pounding blood vessels causing headache. A hot bath is also very (_10_). The steam will sweat out the toxins that cause all the problems.

An election year is one in which all four numbers are evenly divisible by four (1944,1948, etc.). Since 1840, American presidents elected in years ending in zero have been destined to die in office.
William H. Harrison, the man who served the shortest term, died of pneumonia several weeks after his inauguration.
Abraham Lincoln was one of four presidents who were assassinated. He was elected in 1860, and his untimely death came just five years later.
James A. Garfield, a former Union army general from Ohio, was shot during his first year in office (1881) by a man to whom he wouldn’t give a job.
While in his second term of office (1901), William McKinley, another Ohioan, attended the Pan-American Exposition at Buffalo, New York. During the reception, he was assassinated while shaking hands with some of the guests.
Three years after his election in 1920, Warren G. Harding died in office. Although it was never proved, many believe he was poisoned.
Franklin D. Roosevelt had been elected four times (1932,1936,1940, and 1944), the only man to serve so long a term. He had contracted polio in 1921 and died of the illness in 1945.
John F. Kennedy, the last of the line, was assassinated in 1963, only three years after his election.

question.prompt: Which of the following was NOT an election year?
Which president served the shortest term in office?
Which of the following is true?

choices.choice: All presidents elected in years ending in zero have died in office.
Only presidents from Ohio have died in office.
Franklin D. Roosevelt completed four terms as president.
Four American presidents have been assassinated.

question.prompt: How many presidents elected in years ending in zero since 1840 have died in office?
Which of the following presidents was NOT assassinated?

AssessmentItem.Content:
Cars of 2050 will travel the nation's highways in never-before-dreamed-of safety, comfort, and convenience. These cars will float along never touching the ground, and therefore will have no need for wheels.
Annoying highway vibrations, caused by the rotations of the disc-and-tire wheels, will be things of the past. The coming highway passenger cars will literally fly above the road, supported on columns of air compressed by turbine-driven (涡轮驱动的) fans.
The car without wheels has been called a "flying car", and, in a sense, that's just what it is; however, it will not back out of the family garage, start down the street, and then suddenly go quickly upward heading for some distant point. On the contrary, to avoid problems in aerial navigation, the wheelless vehicle probably will travel no more than three inches above road surface. It will travel over fairly rough road and even over smooth water!
The inevitable problems of maritime (水上的) regulations, severe weather conditions, and running out of fuel in remote areas all will require new concepts of operation, servicing, and vehicle regulation.

question.prompt: The author believes that cars of the future ____.

choices.choice: will have wheels unlike those of today
will use columns of air instead of wheels

question.prompt: Cars of the future will run _____.
The car without wheels has been called a "flying car" because _______.

choices.choice: it travels a few inches above the ground
it can fly as a plane does
it moves at a very high speed
it can travel over smooth water

question.prompt: Where is a wheelless car LEAST fit to travel?

AssessmentItem.Content: Planning is a very important activity in our lives. It can give pleasure, even excitement, (_1_) cause quite severe headaches. The more significant the task (_2_) is, the more careful the planning requires. Getting to school or to work on time is a task requiring (_3_) or no planning, and it is almost a (_4_). A month's touring holiday (_5_), or better (_6_), getting married, is a different matter altogether. If the (_7_) involves a church wedding, with fifty guests, a reception, a honeymoon in Venice, and (_8_) to a new home, this requires even more planning to make (_9_) that it is successful. Planning is our way of trying to ensure success and (_10_) avoiding costly failures we cannot afford. It is (_11_) essential to mankind as a (_12_), to individual nations, to families and single people; the (_13_) may vary, but the (_14_) of importance does not. In essence, a nation planning its resources and (_15_) does not differ from the (_16_) weekly shopping or monthly household budget (预算). (_17_) are designed to ensure an adequate supply of essentials, (_18_) a rate of spending within the limits of (_19_), and if properly carried out, will (_20_) shortages, wastage and over-expenditure.
